title: "Diversity Intensity Profitability" Dwayne Beck SDSU Dakota Lakes Research Farm

tasks.task: Conducting no-till farming and soil health management.
subtasks: Planting cover crops like barley, oats, peas, and swathing them to provide residues.
Utilizing forage cover crops for livestock grazing, such as swathing and allowing animals to feed on the residue.
Implementing diverse crop rotations to manage pests, diseases, and improving soil structure.
Monitoring and managing aphid populations using natural predators and fungi.
Employing sanitation practices like rotation and competitive planting to prevent weed outbreaks.
Applying fertilizer close to the crop roots to minimize weed nutrition.
Removing residue (e.g., swathing) to feed livestock and maintain cover.

tasks.task: Managing irrigation systems for efficient water use.
subtasks: Operating center pivots to apply water uniformly and minimize runoff.
Walking behind irrigators during operation to observe and maintain equipment.
Adjusting water application rates based on soil and plant needs.

tasks.task: Conducting field operations and monitoring crop health.
subtasks: Checking crop conditions, such as canopy coverage and weed presence.
Evaluating crop yields and making decisions based on soil moisture and weather.
Implementing integrated pest management strategies, including biological controls.
Analyzing financial data (e.g., grain sales) to justify sustainable farming practices.
Developing and adjusting farming practices based on research and feedback from the agricultural community.

tasks.task: Engaging in agricultural education and outreach.
subtasks: Presenting farm management practices to fellow farmers and researchers.
Sharing knowledge about soil health, cover cropping, and sustainable farming techniques.
